title: Atoms from A to easy!

options.label: B
options.text: To explain the behavior of electrons in an atom

options.label: C
options.text: To show the structure of a molecule

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: A rule that describes how electrons fill energy levels from highest to lowest

options.label: B
options.text: A rule that describes how electrons fill energy levels from lowest to highest

options.label: C
options.text: A rule that describes how protons fill energy levels

options.label: D
options.text: A rule that describes how neutrons fill energy levels

What are valence electrons?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Neutrons in the nucleus of an atom

title: Dark matter: The matter we can't see - James Gillies

multiple-choice.question: What were the four basic elements proposed by the ancient Greeks to make up the universe?
What was the problem with the ancient Greeks' theory of the four elements?

options.label: B
options.text: It didn't predict anything that could be measured

options.label: C
options.text: It didn't include the concept of atoms

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with proposing the idea that everything is made up of tiny, indivisible bits of stuff called atoms?
What percentage of the universe is made up of the ordinary stuff that we can see, according to physicists?
What is the term used to describe the invisible stuff that makes up about 27% of the universe?
How do scientists know that dark matter exists?

options.label: C
options.text: They can measure its effects on visible matter

multiple-choice.question: What is the cosmic microwave background, and what is its significance in the study of dark matter?

options.label: A
options.text: It's the afterglow of the Big Bang, and it provides evidence for dark matter

options.label: B
options.text: It's the light emitted by stars, and it has no relation to dark matter

options.label: C
options.text: It's the heat emitted by galaxies, and it's used to study dark energy

options.label: D
options.text: It's the radiation emitted by black holes, and it's not related to dark matter

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the energy that drives the acceleration of the universe's expansion?
What is supersymmetry (SUSY), and how could it help us understand the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: SUSY is a theory that predicts the existence of new particles that could make up dark matter

options.label: B
options.text: SUSY is a theory that explains the behavior of ordinary matter

options.label: C
options.text: SUSY is a theory that describes the properties of dark energy

options.label: D
options.text: SUSY is a theory that has no relation to the universe

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what percentage of the universe could we potentially understand if we found evidence for supersymmetry (SUSY)?

title: What happened to antimatter? - Rolf Landua

multiple-choice.question: According to Einstein's famous physics formula, what is the relationship between mass and energy?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass and energy are two separate entities that cannot be converted into each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Mass is a form of energy, and they can be converted into each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Energy is a form of mass, but mass cannot be converted into energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass and energy are unrelated concepts in physics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of creating new particles by concentrating a huge amount of energy in a tiny space?
What is the result when a particle and its corresponding antiparticle come into contact with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They combine to form a new particle with increased mass.

options.label: B
options.text: They annihilate each other, releasing a large amount of energy.

options.label: C
options.text: They repel each other, resulting in no change.

options.label: D
options.text: They attract each other, forming a stable bond.

multiple-choice.question: Why is antimatter not commonly used as a source of energy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too expensive to produce.

options.label: B
options.text: It is too difficult to store.

options.label: C
options.text: It takes more energy to create antimatter than is released when it is combined with matter.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a viable source of energy due to its rarity in nature.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated energy content of one gram of antimatter?

options.label: A
options.text: Enough to drive a car 100 times around the Earth

options.label: B
options.text: Enough to bring the space shuttle into orbit

options.label: C
options.text: Enough to drive a car 1,000 times around the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: Enough to power a city for a year

multiple-choice.question: What is the current understanding of the distribution of antimatter in the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a significant amount of antimatter in the visible universe.

options.label: B
options.text: There is no significant amount of antimatter in the visible universe.

options.label: C
options.text: The distribution of antimatter is unknown due to the limitations of current technology.

options.label: D
options.text: Antimatter is only found in certain regions of the universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the unequal distribution of matter and antimatter in the universe?
What is the estimated amount of matter that remained after the initial destruction of matter and antimatter in the early universe?
What is the purpose of experiments at CERN related to antimatter?

options.label: A
options.text: To create large amounts of antimatter for energy production

options.label: B
options.text: To study the properties of antimatter

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the reason for the asymmetry between matter and antimatter

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new technologies for antimatter detection

multiple-choice.question: According to scientists, what would be the result if there was no asymmetry between matter and antimatter in the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe would be filled with radiation only.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe would be composed of equal amounts of matter and antimatter.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe would be devoid of particles.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe would be in a state of equilibrium.

title: How did feathers evolve? - Carl Zimmer

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the skeletons of birds and certain dinosaurs?

options.label: A
options.text: They have an identical bone structure.

options.label: B
options.text: They share some anatomical details, such as wish bones.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a completely different bone structure.

multiple-choice.question: What discovery in the late 1990s supported the idea that birds are living dinosaurs?

options.label: B
options.text: Fossils of birds with dinosaur-like features.

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of a new species of bird.

options.label: D
options.text: The discovery of a new species of dinosaur.

multiple-choice.question: What did the most distant feathered relatives of birds have in terms of feathers?

options.label: B
options.text: Straight feathers that looked like wires.

multiple-choice.question: How did the feathers on dinosaurs change over time?

options.label: A
options.text: They became less complex and less widespread.

options.label: B
options.text: They became more complex and more widespread.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the function of feathers on dinosaurs that were too heavy to fly?

options.label: A
options.text: They were only used for display purposes.

options.label: B
options.text: They were only used for insulation.

options.label: C
options.text: They could have served multiple purposes, such as display, insulation, and camouflage.

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible explanation for how feathered dinosaurs took flight?

options.label: A
options.text: They jumped off cliffs and flapped their arms.

options.label: B
options.text: They flapped their arms as they ran up an incline, using their feathers for extra lift.

options.label: C
options.text: They used their powerful legs to kick off the ground.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a bird using feathers for a purpose other than flight?

options.label: A
options.text: A peacock using its feathers to fly away from predators.

options.label: B
options.text: A woodcock using its feathers to blend in with its forest backdrop.

options.label: C
options.text: An ostrich using its feathers to fly long distances.

options.label: D
options.text: A penguin using its feathers to swim faster.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the evolution of feathers based on the fossil record?

options.label: A
options.text: Feathers evolved suddenly and without intermediate forms.

options.label: B
options.text: Feathers evolved gradually over millions of years with intermediate forms.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that scientists have been able to determine the colors of feathers on dinosaurs?

options.label: A
options.text: By studying the shapes of the feathers.

options.label: B
options.text: By studying the sizes of the feathers.

options.label: C
options.text: By analyzing the molecules preserved in fossils.

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how long after the first wiry feathers evolved did feathers lift dinosaurs into the sky?

title: How to start a movement

multiple-choice.question: What is the main topic of the TED talk?

options.label: B
options.text: The role of the first follower in a movement

options.label: C
options.text: How to make a movement happen

options.label: D
options.text: The characteristics of a good leader

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the crucial role of the first follower?

options.label: B
options.text: To show everyone else how to follow

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the leader embraces the first follower as an equal?

options.label: B
options.text: The movement becomes more about the leader

options.text: The movement becomes more about the followers

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on leadership?

options.label: A
options.text: Leadership is the most important factor in a movement

options.label: C
options.text: Leadership is only for charismatic individuals

options.label: D
options.text: Leadership is not necessary for a movement

options.label: B
options.text: To show the diversity of the followers

options.label: C
options.text: To make the movement more appealing

options.label: D
options.text: Because new followers emulate the followers, not the leader

multiple-choice.question: What is the tipping point in a movement, according to the speaker?

options.label: B
options.text: When the first follower joins in

options.label: C
options.text: When a small group of people join in, creating momentum

multiple-choice.question: How do people who prefer to stick with the crowd behave when a movement gains momentum?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more cautious and hesitant to join

options.label: B
options.text: They join in quickly to avoid being ridiculed for not participating

options.label: C
options.text: They become more critical of the movement

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice to those who want to start a movement?

options.label: A
options.text: Focus on developing your leadership skills

options.label: B
options.text: Have the courage to follow and show others how to follow

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for the right moment to join in

options.label: D
options.text: Try to be the leader of the movement

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the role of the first follower in a movement?

options.label: A
options.text: The first follower is not important

options.label: B
options.text: The first follower is only a supporter of the leader

options.label: C
options.text: The first follower is an underestimated form of leadership

options.label: D
options.text: The first follower is the actual leader of the movement

title: How do you know whom to trust? - Ram Neta

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of our knowledge about the world around us?
Why can't we always trust authorities, even if they are highly respected?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can be dishonest or mistaken

options.label: A
options.text: They gained a lot of money

options.label: B
options.text: They lost a lot of money

multiple-choice.question: How can we distinguish between occasions when we can safely trust authority and when we can't?

options.text: By considering their track record on a particular topic

options.label: B
options.text: If someone is consistently right, we should trust them less

options.label: C
options.text: If someone is consistently right, we should trust them more

options.label: D
options.text: If someone is consistently wrong, we should trust them less

options.label: C
options.text: What's their track record on this topic?

options.label: B
options.text: By considering our track record on similar topics

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of judging our own instincts by their track record?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a more subjective view of ourselves

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to a more objective view of ourselves

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a more emotional view of ourselves

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to a more biased view of ourselves

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to consider an authority's track record on a particular topic?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it guarantees they will always be right

options.label: B
options.text: Because it increases the likelihood they will be right

options.label: C
options.text: Because it decreases the likelihood they will be right

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is irrelevant to their credibility

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of blindly trusting authority without considering their track record?

title: Pool medical patents, save lives - Ellen 't Hoen

multiple-choice.question: What was the main issue faced by the aviation industry in the early 20th century?

options.label: B
options.text: Patent holders defending their patents fiercely

multiple-choice.question: Why was Nelson Odoma unable to access treatment for HIV in 2002?

options.text: He was not aware of the treatment options

options.label: B
options.text: The treatment was not available in his country

options.label: C
options.text: He could not afford the treatment due to high prices

options.label: D
options.text: He was not eligible for treatment

options.label: A
options.text: The price of the medicines increased

options.label: B
options.text: The quality of the medicines decreased

options.label: C
options.text: The price of the medicines decreased significantly

options.label: D
options.text: The availability of the medicines remained unchanged

options.label: A
options.text: Patents are not required for pharmaceuticals

options.label: B
options.text: Patents are required for pharmaceuticals, but only for 10 years

options.label: C
options.text: Patents are required for pharmaceuticals, and must last at least 20 years

options.label: D
options.text: Patents are not necessary for pharmaceuticals in developing countries

multiple-choice.question: What is the "treatment time bomb" referred to in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The increasing number of people infected with HIV

options.label: B
options.text: The decreasing number of people accessing antiretroviral treatment

options.label: C
options.text: The potential crisis caused by new, patented medicines being unaffordable

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of funding for HIV treatment programs

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the airplane patent pool and the Medicines Patent Pool?

options.label: A
options.text: The airplane patent pool was voluntary, while the Medicines Patent Pool is mandatory

options.label: B
options.text: The airplane patent pool was mandatory, while the Medicines Patent Pool is voluntary

options.label: C
options.text: The airplane patent pool only included patents from Western companies, while the Medicines Patent Pool includes patents from all companies

options.label: D
options.text: The airplane patent pool was only for military airplanes, while the Medicines Patent Pool is for all medicines

multiple-choice.question: How does the Medicines Patent Pool work?

options.label: A
options.text: Patent holders are forced to license their patents to the pool

options.label: B
options.text: Patent holders voluntarily license their patents to the pool, which then licenses them to generic manufacturers

options.label: C
options.text: Generic manufacturers are allowed to produce patented medicines without permission from the patent holders

options.label: D
options.text: The pool only includes patents for antiretroviral medicines

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the Medicines Patent Pool for people living with HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the price of antiretroviral medicines

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the quality of antiretroviral medicines

options.label: C
options.text: It makes new, patented medicines available at a lower cost

options.label: D
options.text: It only benefits people living with HIV in developed countries

multiple-choice.question: What is the example given in the transcript of a new medicine being made available through the Medicines Patent Pool?

options.label: A
options.text: A new antiretroviral medicine for children

multiple-choice.question: What is Nelson Odoma's expectation from the Medicines Patent Pool?

options.label: A
options.text: That it will increase the price of antiretroviral medicines

options.label: B
options.text: That it will make new, patented medicines available at a lower cost, without delay

options.label: C
options.text: That it will only benefit people living with HIV in developed countries

options.label: D
options.text: That it will decrease the quality of antiretroviral medicines
